bestBHT.bht: Peter's mother-in-law is suffering from a great fever, described as a severe and possibly chronic condition. St. Luke, a physician, uses the term great to emphasize the intensity of the fever, distinguishing it from milder cases. It is interesting to note that this house becomes Jesus' home in Capernaum. Jesus' miraculous healing of this intense fever showcases his divine power and compassion, offering hope and relief even in the face of challenging and long-lasting illnesses.

Henry Alford: A great fever...divided fevers into great and small.
An epithet used by St. Luke, as a physician.
Understands it only of the intensity of the fever.
Marvin Vincent: Taken. The word is used nine times by Luke, and only three times elsewhere."
Paul uses it of the constraining of Christ's love (2 Corinthians 5:14), and of being in a strait (Philippians 1:23)."
The epithet great is peculiar to Luke. The ancient physicians distinguished fevers into great and small.
Archibald T. Robertson: This house came also to be the Capernaum home of Jesus.
The word πενθερα for mother-in-law is old and well established in usage.
Periphrastic imperfect passive, the analytical tense accenting the continuous fever, perhaps chronic and certainly severe.
John Gill: The fever is 'a disease, or rather a class of diseases, whose characteristic is a preternatural heat felt through the whole body, or, at least, the principal parts thereof, attended with other symptoms.'

A fever is an inseparable companion of an inflammation. The symptoms are many: every fever, arising from any internal cause, is attended with a quick pulse, and unusual heat at different times, and in different degrees.
The fever Peter's wife's mother lay ill of, is said to be a 'great one'; which circumstance is the rather mentioned, to illustrate the miraculous cure of it by Christ.

bhtAttempts.bht: In Luke 4:38, we find that Peter's mother-in-law is suffering from a great fever. St. Luke, being a physician, understands this fever to be of great intensity, and he uses the term great to distinguish it from lesser fevers. This continuous and severe fever, potentially chronic, was causing significant distress. It is interesting to note that this house in Capernaum became Jesus' home. The word mother-in-law used here is an old and well-established term. The miraculous healing of this great fever by Jesus serves to highlight the power of his divine intervention.

In this passage, Luke describes Peter's mother-in-law suffering from a great fever, which is understood to be a severe and possibly chronic condition. This intensity is emphasized by the use of the epithet great, a term Luke, as a physician, employs to distinguish it from milder fevers. The fact that this house eventually becomes Jesus' home in Capernaum adds significance to this healing account. By miraculously curing this intense fever, Jesus demonstrates his divine power and ability to bring relief in even the most challenging circumstances.

In this account, we learn that Peter's mother-in-law is afflicted with a severe and possibly chronic fever. The term great is used by St. Luke, who, as a physician, distinguishes between fevers of varying intensities. It is noteworthy that this house eventually becomes Jesus' home in Capernaum. By miraculously healing this intense fever, Jesus demonstrates his divine power and ability to bring relief in the face of challenging illnesses.

Peter's mother-in-law is suffering from a great fever, described as a severe and possibly chronic condition. St. Luke, a physician, uses the term great to emphasize the intensity of the fever, distinguishing it from milder cases. It is interesting to note that this house becomes Jesus' home in Capernaum. Jesus' miraculous healing of this intense fever showcases his divine power and compassion, offering hope and relief even in the face of challenging and long-lasting illnesses.

Peter's mother-in-law is suffering from a great fever, characterized as a severe and possibly chronic condition. This intense fever is described by St. Luke, an esteemed physician, who uses the epithet great to distinguish it from lesser fevers. We observe that this house eventually becomes Jesus' home in Capernaum. Jesus demonstrates his divine power by miraculously healing this intense fever, showcasing his capacity to bring relief even in the most challenging and enduring illnesses.
